Vienna, ÖnB, cod.652, fol. 2v (Fulda, 2nd quarter of the 9th century): Hrabanus (left) and Alcuin (middle) dedicate a work to Archbishop Otgar of Mainz (Right). As the teacher (with more seniority), Alcuin has his arm around Hrabanus’ shoulder, expressing his support when introducing him to the Archbishop.
resource: Vienna, ÖnB, cod.652, fol. 2v (Fulda, 2nd quarter of the 9th century)

description: Paris, BnF, lat. 6734, fol. 3r: Imaginary portrait of Johannes Scottus (on the right) in Honorius of Autun’s Clavis physicae. John the Scot engages in a discussion with ‘Abbot Theodorus’ about his theological treatise on the creation of the world, the Periphyseon. Theodorus holds a banner with the text: “he reveals the light of dogma by the sharpness of his mind”, and John Scottus holds a banner saying: “He seeks to make hidden things clarify themselves.”

Paris, BnF, lat. 11127, f. 49r: Different terms are used to introduce the interlinear gloss. These include abbreviations for ‘scilicet’ (‘s’) and ‘id est’ (‘i’), both meaning ‘that is’ and offering explanations of Boethius’ wording.

Paris, BnF, lat. 11127, f. 49r: Different terms are used to introduce the interlinear gloss. These include abbreviations for ‘scilicet’ (‘s’) and ‘id est’ (‘i’), both meaning ‘that is’ and offering explanations of Boethius’ wording.
Paris, BnF, lat. 11127, f. 49r: Here the word ‘exemplum’, ‘example’, has been added above the word ‘dico’, ‘I say’, in the text, indicating that Boethius is about to introduce an example.
Paris, BnF, lat. 11127, f. 49r: Keywords are used summarise main points of the text.
Paris, BnF, lat. 11127, f. 49r: Here a later reader has noted that the second book of the text starts here.
Paris, BnF, lat. 11127, f. 49r: The gloss in this case is a correction, supplying text missed by the scribe.

Decorated initial from BnF lat. 7740, f. 1r, depicting Cicero and Plato arguing over the nature of rhetoric.
Leiden UB, VLQ 33, f. 1v: Depiction of Rhetoric as a female warrior (on the left) in conversation with two figures dressed in antiquated clothing.
Leiden, UB, BPL 1925, f. 139v: example of a text with a narrow margin and only occasional notes. The book is only ca 13,5 cm high.

alttext: Chantilly, Musée Condé, MS 291 (660), f. 1r. Bruges, c. 1470-1480.
description: Chantilly, Musée Condé, MS 291 (660), f. 1r. Bruges, c. 1470-1480: Portrait of a medieval scholar ‘in his study’, consulting multiple books and taking notes. The books are organized for consultation on a caroussel, a shelf that can spin around to have multiple books at hand.
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 4v (c 1250-1275, Paris): Short summaries or marginal indices make clear what the reader can find in the text, which makes the text easier to consult

Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 6v
Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 7r: A bad spot and tear in the parchment were already there before the writing started: the scribe carefully writes around it.

Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 7v: This set up of the two faces that link the note in the margin to the correct place in the text confirms that the faces are part of the thirteenth-century layer of reader’s notes, and not the original tenth-century one.
Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 30v-32r
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 68v (detail)
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 72v (detail)
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 73v (detail)
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 45v (detail)

Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 11r: ‘Rara est adeo concordia formae atque pudicitiae’: ‘Beauty rarely coincides with chastity’ (Juvenal, Satires, 10.295) – gloss to De inventione I.XXIV.35, where Cicero notes that a person could be either handsome or ugly.

Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 41v: ‘Facilius est commendare paupertatem quam sustinere’: ‘It is easier to praise poverty than to put up with it’. The quotation is attributed to ‘Seneca’ and paraphrases Seneca the Elder’s Controversiae II.18. The passage glosses the question of appropriate reward for virtuous acts (De inventione, II.XXXIX.115)

Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 70r: ‘Nichil est iniquius his qui nusquam putant esse subtilitatem nisi ubi nihil est praeter subtilitatem’: ‘Nothing is more unfair than to think that acuteness is only present when there is nothing present but acuteness’. Quoting again from Seneca the Elder (Controversiae, I.21, trans. Winterbottom, LCL 463, p. 21), the quotation glosses Rhetorica ad Herennium II.XI.16, which concerns the dangers of ambiguous oratory.
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 25r: Who is Magister Iohannes de P[arvi?] ponte? Was he, like Adamus Parvipontus [link], a master who taught on the petit pont in Paris?
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 61r: Who is Magister Alexander, referred to here in a gloss to the Rhetorica ad Herennium?
Leiden, BPL 139B, f. 44v: This little sketch in the margin represents another manner of visualising the finite number of pairings of the predicables
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 32v: the quires are 'numbered' with letters

alttext: Cologny, Fondation Martin Bodmer, Cod. Bodmer 127, f. 244r
description: Selfportrait of ‘Frater Rufillus’ in a 12th-century manuscript from (possibly) Weissenau, who depicts himself decorating the manuscript. Cologny, Fondation Martin Bodmer, Cod. Bodmer 127, f. 244r (detail).

Ramon Llull was also a frequent user of the library of Sorbonne. In 1311 he donated a copy of his works to the library and requested that it would be chained to the bookcase; a common but not so subtle way of preventing a book from being stolen.

Leiden, UB, VLQ 103, f. 1r (photo MT): Opening of Cicero’s De inventione. This manuscript was part of Richard’s collection (Biblionomia, 27), before being included in Gerard d’Abbeville’s bequest to the Sorbonne.

Leiden, UB, VLQ 103, f. 14 (photo MT): Richard’s entry for this book reads‘[Cicero’s] first book on rhetoric and his second ad herennium in one volume whose sign is the letter C’, the letter indicating the classification of the manuscript in his collection (Paris, Bibliothèque de Sorbonne, MS 636, f. 9r)

alttext: Brussels, KB 5169, fol. 42r copyright Brussels, Koninklijke Bibliotheek, Special Collections
description: Brussels, KB, Ms. 5169, fol. 42r: In this ninth-century manuscript of Prosper of Aquitaine’s chronicle, snakes in the margin warn the reader that a heretic is about to enter the narrative. The use of this symbol points to a close association between serpents and heretics.

alttext: Facsimile made in 1818 of a lost original of Herrad of Landsberg, Hortus Deliciarum
description: Detail from an illustration in the Hortus deliciarum, the first encyclopedia written by a woman. The author is Herrad of Landsberg, abbess of Hohenberg. The manuscript was made around 1180 and kept in the Bibliothèque municipale of Strassbourg. It was destroyed in a fire in 1870, but several copies of the illustrations were made in the course of the 19th century. This reproduction was made in 1818.

Valenciennes, BM, Ms. 320 (304), f. 138r (detail): Thomas of Cantimpré, De natura rerum, De scorpione: “According to Solinus, the scorpion is a serpent with a friendly face like a maiden but has a poisonous sting in Its knotty tail”.

West door, Cathedral of Chartres, c. 1150. The throne of wisdom, framed by the liberal arts. The complex iconographical program is believed to have been designed by the scholar Thierry of Chartres, chancellor of the cathedral school from 1141 to c. 1155. Famous twelfth-century scholars such as William of Conches, John of Salisbury and Gilbert of Poitiers studied in Chartres.
Below each art is a famous practictioner. Dialectica is seated above (or supported by) Aristotle
Aristotle is depicted as the architect of thought
Dialectica from close up. the creature she is holding is according to some scholars a serpent, according to others a scorpion
Sculpture of Lady Dialectica next to Lady Grammar. Porch of the Münster of Freiburg in Breisgau, 13th century
Admont, Benediktinerstift, Cod. 128, f. 13v
Admont, Benediktinerstift, Cod. 128, f. 13v: The attribute of the treacherous serpent has disappeared. It is replaced by rational, step by step argumentation.

alttext: Lyon, BM 244, f. 69v Paris, s. 13 ¾
description: Lyon, BM, Ms. 244 (176) (Paris, ca 1250-1275), f. 69v: Dialectica looks positively saintly in this illustration. She holds a fleur de lis, symbol of the virgin Mary. This meek damsel is a far cry from the dangerous lady depicted by Martianus and Alanus
Christ as a warrior, treading on the beasts. Mosaic in the Archbishop’s Chapel Ravenna, sixth century

Typus Logice, woodcut 1517. Logica (dialectic) is depicted as a huntress. With her two dogs, veritas and falsitas, she pursues the hare problema in the wood of opinions. Gregor Reisch, Margarita Philosophica Encyclopedia of the liberal arts Basel, 1517

alttext: Montpellier, BU Médecine H 437, 1340, f.57v Gossuin de Metz, Image du monde Encyclopedia, discussion of dialectic
description: Montpellier, BU Médecine, H. 437 (1340, Gossuin de Metz, Image du monde), f. 57v: A woman and a clerc disputing.

Crypt of the Basilica Santa Eulalia in Mérida, rebuilt in the 13th century, after the Reconquista of 1229
Valenciennes, BM, Ms.150 (St. Amand, c. 881), f. 141v: Song of Saint Eulalia. The verses are written in the langue d’oil, the vernacular language of the northern half of medieval France.

alttext: Den Haag, KB, KA 20, c.1325-35, f. 208r
description: Den Haag, KB, KA 20 (Jacob van Maerlant, Spiegel historiael, ca. 1325-1335), f. 208r: Portrait of Charlemagne's court

Reims, Bibliothèque Carnegie, Ms. 385 (9th century), f. 158r: Alcuin’s letter to Gundrada/Eulalia. This manuscript forms a dossier on adoptionism. The letter to Gundrada follows the Confessio of Felix (top of the folio).
Chantilly, Musée Condé, Ms. 482 (Roman de la Rose, Paris, 1350-1360), f. 60v: Portrait of Abelard and Heloise
Chantilly, Musée Condé, Ms. 482 (Roman de la Rose, Paris, 1350-1360), f. 60v: Portrait of Abelard and Heloise

alttext: Psychomachia London, BL, Cotton Cleopatra C VIII, f. 11r
description: London, BL, Cotton Cleopatra C VIII, f. 11r: Female personifications of the virtue ‘Long-suffering’ and the vice ‘wrath’ engaging in combat in Prudentius’ Psychomachia. Below, Wrath has thrown down her weapons in defeat (but is still arguing)
Troyes, BM, Ms. 60 (Gratianus, Decretum, ca. 1150-1175, Northern Italy), f. 132v: clerics in dispute
Reconstruction of the palace at Aachen in the 9th c.

Vercelli, Bibliotheca Capitulare, ms. 165 (The Canons of Councils, manuscript made around 800, perhaps in Milan), f. 2v, 3v. Emperor Constantine presiding over discussions at the Council of Nicaea (323), where the heresy of Arius was condemned. Photo Warren Pezé

description: Vercelli, Bibliotheca Capitulare, ms. 165, f. 4v-5r: Emperor Theodosius the Great. Presiding over the council of Constantinople (381). Photo Warren Pezé
resource: Copyright: Biblioteca Capitulare, Vercelli. Photo by Warren Pezé

description: Paris, BnF, lat. 1572 (Acts of the Council of Ephese, manuscript made in the 8th century in Tours), f. 78v-79r: The letters s (scribe) and d (dimitte) in the right margin are in the hand of Alcuin or his assistant. They indicate what should be copied and what not in his dossier against Felix.
Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, Ms 23, f. 18r: Prudentius, Psychomachia. Manuscript made in the first half of the 11th century.
Cyril of Alexandria
Reims, Bibliothèque Carnegie, Ms. 385 (9th century), f. 154r: Felix, Confessio fidei.  “Profession of faith of Felix bishop of the see of Urgel which he brought forth himself to spurn his error”
Reims, Bibliothèque Carnegie, Ms. 385 (9th century), f. 156r
Karlsruhe, BadischeLandesbibliothek, St. Peter Perg. 92: Set of miniatures illustrating the life of Raimundus Lullus
Saint Dominic and the Albigenses (1480). A painting by Pedro Berruguete (c. 1450-1504) depicting Dominic, founder of the Inquisition, checking books for heresy with a trial by fire.

Cambrai, BM, MS 620 (572), f. 1r (detail). The author, Giovanni di Andrea (c 1270-1348), in his study, surrounded by books in chests, bookcases and on his desk. A special carousel (a wooden wheel on which multiple books could be laid out) allows him to consult multiple books at a time. Depicted in a manuscript made c. 1340-1345 in Bologna.
Paris, BnF, Fr. 12584 (Roman de Renart, manuscript made in North-East France, c.1300-1350), f. 61r (detail): Peculiar pointing hands
Saint-Omer, BASO, Ms. 118, f. 1v: Manuscript with works of of Richard of St. Victor, made in North France in the first third of the 13th century.

Paris, BnF, Lat. 15350, f. 1r (detail): Here is a detail from a manuscript with quodlibetical disputations from, among others, Thomas Aquinas. The structure of the disputation is clear, with three questions (‘tria sunt quesita’, and further division of these into subquestions with ‘utrum’ (‘whether’).
Lyon, BM, MS 128 (060), f. 2r: Rhetorical manual from the 15th century, with Rhetorica ad Herennium and, among others, an ars praedicandi.

alttext: Cologny, Fondation Martin Bodmer, Cod. Bodmer 188, f. 10r (detail)
description: Cologny, Fondation Martin Bodmer, Cod. Bodmer 188, f. 10r (detail): manuscript from the thirteenth century with the Dragmaticon of William of Conches. In this image Logica is a part of Philosophia, and Dialectica is a part of Logica.

alttext: Photo of the monastery of St. Germain and the church in modern times
description: Photo of the monastery of St. Germain and the church in modern times

alttext: Paris, Bibliothèque de l'Arsenal, MS 702, f. 98r: detail
description: Paris, Bibliothèque de l'Arsenal, MS 702, f. 98r (detail)
The Schoyen Collection, Ms. 712: Rebdorf Psalter with a gloss from Anselm of Laon
Valenciennes, BM, Ms. 396 (379) (manuscript made in Northern France, c. 1250-1275, Papias the Grammarian, Elementarium doctrinae rudimentum), f. 167r: disputing masters
Paris, BnF, lat. 13368 (Fleury, twelfth century), f. 146r: "Petri abaelardi iunioris palatini summi peripatetici." (Peter Abelard, the younger supreme peripatetic of Le Pallet)

alttext: Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek Cod. 29 (878), p. 171: Porphyry’s Isagoge
description: Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Cod. 29 (878), p. 171: Porphyry’s Isagoge
Karlsruhe, BadischeLandesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 5r

description: Paris, Bibliothèque de l’Institut de France, Ms. 264, f. 1r: Boethius in his prison, discussing with Philosophy. Manuscript made around 1400 in Northern France (possibly Paris).
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 4v
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 2v: Once spotted, we see them in more places. Do you see them in between the lines on this page?
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 4v: Hand of Rather
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v (detail): Rather of Verona also used a bit of empty space on the last page of the manuscript to write a short letter.
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 66v: the names of other authorities (Augustine, Plato, Pythagoras, Boethius, Pliny)

Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Cod. 315 (605), p. 130: Initial ‘G’ with added penwork detail.
Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Cod. 315 (605), p. 121: Note the lead outline of the initial ‘P’ which was marked out to guide the rubricator.

alttext: Breviculum ex artibus Raimundi Lulli electum – Karlruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 4r (detail).
description: Karlsruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92 (Breviculum ex artibus Raimundi Lulli electum), f. 4r (detail). The image shows Ramon Llull sitting on an elevated chair, teaching an attentive crowd. He discusses (in green letters) how to distinguish between right and false arguments and opinions.

alttext: Karlsruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92,
description: Karlsruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 6v: The army is lead by by Aristotle, riding his horse ‘Ratiocinatio’ (reasoning). Averroes follows, on the horse, ‘Ymaginatio’ (imagination).

alttext: Karlsruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92,
description: Karlsruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 6v: In the tower of falsehood rhetorical and dialectical sins are found, such as ignorance, confusion, impossibility, emptyness. Truth is held capture in the dungeon.

alttext: Karlsruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92,
description: Karlsruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 7r: Ramon Lull pulls a chariot with eighteen principles of the art of arguing well: among them are goodness, greatness, wisdom, endurance, etc.

alttext: Karlsruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92,
description: Karlsruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 28v (detail): Note that the circle on the bottom right is designed to become part of an assembled stack of circles, which can then be moved to make different combinations.

alttext: Museo dell’ Opera del Duomo, Florence.
description: Plato and Aristotle in dispute. The relief represents the art of dialectic and is part of a series of the seven liberal arts made by Lucca della Robbia for the belltower of the Duomo in Florence, 15th century. Museo dell’ Opera del Duomo, Florence.

alttext: Fresco by Pellegrino Tibaldi, c. 1588- 1599, Madrid, El Escoria.
description: Zeno of Elea shows youths the door to truth and falsity. Fresco by Pellegrino Tibaldi, c. 1588- 1599, Madrid, El Escoria.

alttext: c. 470 BC Louvre, department of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Antiquities, G384
description: Boxing scene: athletes in guard position. Detail from an Attic cup, c. 470 BC Louvre, department of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Antiquities, G384
Brussels, KB, Ms. 5169, fol. 42r

alttext: Verona, Bibl. Capitolare CCLI, thirteenth century, f. 10r.
description: Verona, Bibl. Capitolare CCLI (Illustrated copy of Alanus de Insulis’ Anticlaudianus, 13th century), f. 10r: The liberal arts are building a cart.

Paris, BnF, lat. 4886 (11th-century manuscript made in Rippol), f. 48v: A note in the margin reads: “heresim elipanti toletane et felicis urgelletane episcopis […] ta et erradicata” (The heresy of bishops Elipand of Toledo and Felix bishop of Urgell [….] and erradicated).

Baptism of Christ.  Mosaic in Arian baptistry in Ravenna. The baptistry was built by King Theoderic the Great around 500. The fact that Christ is depicted as a young and beardless man is meant to convey that Christ the Son is inferior to God the Father and not ‘of one substance’ with him.

alttext: Biblioteca del Monasterio de El Escorial, D. I. I., f. 129v
description: Council of Toledo (generic illustration, representing each Visigothic council held in Toledo in the sixth and seventh centuries) Codex Emilianensis, c. 992 Biblioteca del Monasterio de El Escorial, D. I. I., f. 129v
Tʻang dynasty fragmentary silk painting, ninth century. Christian saint, possibly a Nestorian image of Jesus Christ. British museum, asset 1613030451
Reconstruction of the image

Charlemagne’s throne at the Palatine Chapel in Aachen
Paris, BnF, lat. 1572 (manuscript made in Tours in the 8th century), f. 79r. Photo IvR

Paris, BnF, lat. 2848, f. 1r: Alcuin, Seven Books Against Felix (Adversus Felicem). Manuscript made in theTours area in the ninth century. The Books Against Felix were based on research Alcuin had undertaken in preparation for the disputation

alttext: Paris, BnF, lat. 2853, f. 7r Lyon, ninth century
description: Paris, BnF, lat. 2853, f. 7r: Manuscript made in Lyon in the ninth century
Dijon, BM, Ms. 132 (99) (Cîteaux, Abbey of Notre-Dame, 12th century), f. 1r: Jerome delivers his work to Marcella, accompanied by her student Principia

Munich, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, Clm 17092 (c. 1160), f. 130v: Author’s portrait of Origen, pen-and-ink drawing. Above the portrait is written: “scribere cum penna (d)oceat me sacrata maria” – “May the blessed Mary teach me to write with a pen”.

alttext: St. Gallen, Stiftsbibliothek, Cod. sang. 134, p. 2
description: St. Gallen, Stiftsbibliothek, Cod. sang. 134, p. 2
Martyrdom of St. Eulalia of Mérida, 1427-1437 by the Catalan artist Bernat Mortorell. Vic, Museu Episcopal de Vic.

Reims, Bibliothèque Carnegie, Ms. 385, f. 159r: Alcuin offers words of praise: “novi prudentiam vestram optime in dialecticae eruditam esse” (I knew you to be well versed in the subtleties of dialectic).
Catherine and the spiked breaking wheel. Fresco in the Cathedral of Notre Dame, Le Puy-en-Velay, c. 1200. Photo Richard Stracke

alttext: Paris, BnF. Lat. 1970, f. 54r. Fécamp, eleventh century.
description: Paris, BnF, lat. 1970 (Fécamp, 11th century), f. 54r: The Martyrdom of Saint Katharine/Passio Sanctae Catharinae

alttext: mural in the cathedral of La Seu d’Urgell
description: The murals were removed from the cathedral of La Seu d’Urgell between 1927 and 1933 and are now in the Museu Nacional d’Art de Catalunya.
Melk, Benediktinerstift, Cod. 516 (26, A 29)

Paris, BnF. Lat. 14511 (Heloise, Problemata; manuscript made in St. Victor around 1400), f. 17v-18r: This section of the manuscript was copied for the humanist scholar Simon Plumetot (1371-1443), who collected texts written by Abelard, which perhaps explains the added title at the top of the page. Plumetot donated this and other manuscripts related to Abelard to the abbey of St-Victor, where he had studied.
Paris, BnF, lat. 14511, f. 44v: “Incipit sermo magistri abaelardi ad virgines paraclitenses de studio litterarum”
Paris, BnF. Lat. 12949, f. 23v

alttext: Paris, BnF. Lat. 12949, f.23 bis r
description: Paris, BnF, Lat. 12949, f. 23v: Underlined are: versuS iohanni Scotti, bedae, Virgilii, Prudentii, Persii, epitaphium sancti augustini. “Vivere post obitus vatem vis nosse viator? Quod legis, ecce loquor, vox tua nempe mea est” “Passerby, do you wish to know how poets still live after death? Those words you read, behold I speak. Your voice is very much mine” [Possidius, Vita Augustini, 3.18]

Angers, Bibliothèque Municipale, MS 478 (462) (manuscript from around 1400, made in England), p. 28: Portrait of Aristotle

Basel, Universitätsbibliothek, F I 1, fol. 247r (detail): opening page of Aristotle’s Posterior Analytics with a large commentary. Manuscript made in France at the beginning of the fourteenth century.

alttext: Paris, Bibliothèque de l’Institut de France, 264, f. 1r.
description: Paris, Bibliothèque de l’Institut de France, 264  (manuscript made around 1400 in Northern France, possibly Paris), f. 1r: Boethius in his prison, discussing with Philosophy.

Avranches, Bibliothèque Municipale, Ms. 228 (manuscript made in Northern France (perhaps in Paris), ca 1225-1250), fol. 39r: Two philosophers, probably Aristotle and Boethius, engaged in a discussion.

alttext: St. Gallen, Stiftsbibliothek, Cod. Sang. 274, fol. 5r
description: St. Gallen, Stiftsbibliothek, Cod. Sang. 274, fol. 5r (detail): Opening of the Categoriae Decem in a heavily annotated manuscript made in Sankt Gallen in the ninth century.

Cicero in his study in manuscript The Hague, KB, 66 B 13, fol. 245r (detail). The manuscript is a late fifteenth-century illustrated manuscript of the French translation of Valerius Maximus, “Des faits et dits mémorables”. It was made in the Loire valley.
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 2r (detail): The opening of Martianus Capella’s De nuptiis
Paris, BnF, lat. 7730, fol. 1r (detail): Opening of Fortunatianus’ treatise on Rhetoric. Ninth-century manuscript from Fleury
Paris, Bibliothèque Mazarine, Ms. 3795 (manuscript made in 1484), fol. 10r: Porphyrian tree.
Macon, Bibliothèque Municipale, MS 2 (manuscript made in northern France (Paris?) in 1480), fol. 19r (detail): Augustine is disputing with philosophers
Paris, BnF, Lat. 15140, fol. 65v (detail): the section on Memory starts with a decorated initial. Manuscript from the second half of the twelfth century, made in western France.

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v: Here you can see how a little ‘Porphyrian tree’ has been added in the inner margin even when there was hardly space
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v: Here you can see how a later reader added large ‘NOTA’ signs as tiemarks, to clear up the puzzle of where to place the gloss.

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v: Here you can see how a first reader went really fancyfull with inventing a new tiemark, and how a later reader drew a line between text and gloss to mark them off a bit more clearly
